trans-unit.source: Using checkpoints to revert virtual machines to a previous state
trans-unit.target: Using checkpoints to revert virtual machines to a previous state

trans-unit.source: Checkpoints provide a fast and easy way to revert the virtual machine to a previous state.
trans-unit.target: Checkpoints provide a fast and easy way to revert the virtual machine to a previous state.

trans-unit.source: This is especially helpful when you are about to make a change to a virtual machine and you want to be able to roll-back to the present state if that change cause issues.
trans-unit.target: This is especially helpful when you are about to make a change to a virtual machine and you want to be able to roll-back to the present state if that change cause issues.

trans-unit.source: Enable or disable checkpoints
trans-unit.target: Enable or disable checkpoints

trans-unit.source: In **Hyper-V Manager**, right-click the name of the virtual machine, and click **Settings**.
trans-unit.target: In **Hyper-V Manager**, right-click the name of the virtual machine, and click **Settings**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Management** section, select **Checkpoints**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Management** section, select **Checkpoints**.

trans-unit.source: To allow checkpoints to be taken off this virtual machine, make sure Enable Checkpoints is selected -- this is the default behavior.
trans-unit.target: To allow checkpoints to be taken off this virtual machine, make sure Enable Checkpoints is selected -- this is the default behavior.

trans-unit.source: To disable checkpoints, deselect the **Enable Checkpoints** check box.
trans-unit.target: To disable checkpoints, deselect the **Enable Checkpoints** check box.

trans-unit.source: Click **Apply** to apply your changes.
trans-unit.target: Click **Apply** to apply your changes.

trans-unit.source: If you are done, click **OK** to close the dialog box.
trans-unit.target: If you are done, click **OK** to close the dialog box.

trans-unit.source: Choose standard or production checkpoints
trans-unit.target: Choose standard or production checkpoints

trans-unit.source: There are two types of checkpoints:
trans-unit.target: There are two types of checkpoints:

trans-unit.source: **Production checkpoints** -- Used mainly on servers in production environments as a form of backup.
trans-unit.target: **Production checkpoints** -- Used mainly on servers in production environments as a form of backup.

trans-unit.source: **Standard checkpoints** -- Used in development or testing environments to allow rollback if a change fails.
trans-unit.target: **Standard checkpoints** -- Used in development or testing environments to allow rollback if a change fails.

trans-unit.source: Both types of checkpoints restore a virtual machine to a previous state.
trans-unit.target: Both types of checkpoints restore a virtual machine to a previous state.

trans-unit.source: Production checkpoints create an application-consistent checkpoint of a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Production checkpoints create an application-consistent checkpoint of a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: That means the saved virtual machine will resume with no application state.
trans-unit.target: That means the saved virtual machine will resume with no application state.

trans-unit.source: Standard checkpoints (formerly known as snapshots) capture the exact memory state of your virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Standard checkpoints (formerly known as snapshots) capture the exact memory state of your virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: That means the virtual machine will restore with **exactly** the same state in which the checkpoint was taken down to the exact application state.
trans-unit.target: That means the virtual machine will restore with **exactly** the same state in which the checkpoint was taken down to the exact application state.

trans-unit.source: Standard checkpoints may contain information about client connections, transactions, and the external network state.
trans-unit.target: Standard checkpoints may contain information about client connections, transactions, and the external network state.

trans-unit.source: This information may not be valid when the checkpoint is applied.
trans-unit.target: This information may not be valid when the checkpoint is applied.

trans-unit.source: Additionally, if a checkpoint is taken during an application crash, restoring that checkpoint will be in the middle of that crash.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, if a checkpoint is taken during an application crash, restoring that checkpoint will be in the middle of that crash.

trans-unit.source: The presence of a standard checkpoint for a virtual machine may impact the disk performance of the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: The presence of a standard checkpoint for a virtual machine may impact the disk performance of the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: We do not recommend using standard checkpoints on virtual machines when performance or the availability of storage space is critical.
trans-unit.target: We do not recommend using standard checkpoints on virtual machines when performance or the availability of storage space is critical.

trans-unit.source: Applying a production checkpoint involves booting the guest operating system from an offline state.
trans-unit.target: Applying a production checkpoint involves booting the guest operating system from an offline state.

trans-unit.source: This means that no application state or security information is captured as part of the checkpoint process.
trans-unit.target: This means that no application state or security information is captured as part of the checkpoint process.

trans-unit.source: The following table shows when to use production checkpoints or standard checkpoints, depending on the state of the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: The following table shows when to use production checkpoints or standard checkpoints, depending on the state of the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Virtual Machine State
trans-unit.target: Virtual Machine State

trans-unit.source: Production Checkpoint
trans-unit.target: Production Checkpoint

trans-unit.source: Standard Checkpoint
trans-unit.target: Standard Checkpoint

trans-unit.source: Running with Integration Services
trans-unit.target: Running with Integration Services

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: Running without Integration Services
trans-unit.target: Running without Integration Services

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: Offline - no saved state
trans-unit.target: Offline - no saved state

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: Offline - with saved state
trans-unit.target: Offline - with saved state

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: Paused
trans-unit.target: Paused

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: To see the difference between Standard and Production checkpoints, look at the [checkpoints walkthrough](../quick_start/walkthrough_checkpoints.md).
trans-unit.target: To see the difference between Standard and Production checkpoints, look at the [checkpoints walkthrough](../quick_start/walkthrough_checkpoints.md).

trans-unit.source: Set a default checkpoint type
trans-unit.target: Set a default checkpoint type

trans-unit.source: In **Hyper-V Manager**, right-click the name of the virtual machine, and click **Settings**.
trans-unit.target: In **Hyper-V Manager**, right-click the name of the virtual machine, and click **Settings**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Management** section, select **Checkpoints**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Management** section, select **Checkpoints**.

trans-unit.source: Select either production checkpoints or standard checkpoints.
trans-unit.target: Select either production checkpoints or standard checkpoints.

trans-unit.source: If you choose production checkpoints, you can also specify whether the host should take a standard checkpoint if a production checkpoint cannot be taken.
trans-unit.target: If you choose production checkpoints, you can also specify whether the host should take a standard checkpoint if a production checkpoint cannot be taken.

trans-unit.source: If you clear this check box and a production checkpoint cannot be taken, no checkpoint will be selected.
trans-unit.target: If you clear this check box and a production checkpoint cannot be taken, no checkpoint will be selected.

trans-unit.source: If you want to change the location where the configuration files for the checkpoint are stored, change the path in the **Checkpoint File Location** section.
trans-unit.target: If you want to change the location where the configuration files for the checkpoint are stored, change the path in the **Checkpoint File Location** section.

trans-unit.source: Click **Apply** to apply your changes.
trans-unit.target: Click **Apply** to apply your changes.

trans-unit.source: If you are done, click **OK** to close the dialog box.
trans-unit.target: If you are done, click **OK** to close the dialog box.

trans-unit.source: The default behavior in Windows 10 for new virtual machines is to create production checkpoints with fallback to standard checkpoints
trans-unit.target: The default behavior in Windows 10 for new virtual machines is to create production checkpoints with fallback to standard checkpoints

trans-unit.source: Create a checkpoint
trans-unit.target: Create a checkpoint

trans-unit.source: To create a checkpoint
trans-unit.target: To create a checkpoint

trans-unit.source: In **Hyper-V Manager**, under **Virtual Machines**, select the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: In **Hyper-V Manager**, under **Virtual Machines**, select the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the name of the virtual machine, and then click **Checkpoint**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the name of the virtual machine, and then click **Checkpoint**.

trans-unit.source: When the process is complete, the checkpoint will appear under **Checkpoints** in the **Hyper-V Manager**.
trans-unit.target: When the process is complete, the checkpoint will appear under **Checkpoints** in the **Hyper-V Manager**.

trans-unit.source: Apply a checkpoint
trans-unit.target: Apply a checkpoint

trans-unit.source: If you want to revert your virtual machine to a previous point-in-time, you can apply an existing checkpoint.
trans-unit.target: If you want to revert your virtual machine to a previous point-in-time, you can apply an existing checkpoint.

trans-unit.source: In **Hyper-V Manager**, under **Virtual Machines**, select the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: In **Hyper-V Manager**, under **Virtual Machines**, select the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: In the Checkpoints section, right-click the checkpoint that you want to use and click **Apply**.
trans-unit.target: In the Checkpoints section, right-click the checkpoint that you want to use and click **Apply**.

trans-unit.source: A dialog box appears with the following options:
trans-unit.target: A dialog box appears with the following options:

trans-unit.source: Delete a checkpoint
trans-unit.target: Delete a checkpoint

trans-unit.source: To cleanly delete a checkpoint:
trans-unit.target: To cleanly delete a checkpoint:

trans-unit.source: In **Hyper-V Manager**, select the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: In **Hyper-V Manager**, select the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: In the **Checkpoints** section, right-click the checkpoint that you want to delete, and click Delete.
trans-unit.target: In the **Checkpoints** section, right-click the checkpoint that you want to delete, and click Delete.

trans-unit.source: You can also delete a checkpoint and all subsequent checkpoints.
trans-unit.target: You can also delete a checkpoint and all subsequent checkpoints.

trans-unit.source: To do so, right-click the earliest checkpoint that you want to delete, and then click ****Delete Checkpoint** Subtree**.
trans-unit.target: To do so, right-click the earliest checkpoint that you want to delete, and then click ****Delete Checkpoint** Subtree**.

trans-unit.source: You might be asked to verify that you want to delete the checkpoint.
trans-unit.target: You might be asked to verify that you want to delete the checkpoint.

trans-unit.source: Confirm that it is the correct checkpoint, and then click **Delete**.
trans-unit.target: Confirm that it is the correct checkpoint, and then click **Delete**.

trans-unit.source: The .avhdx and .vhdx files will merge, and when complete, the .avhdx file will be deleted from the file system.
trans-unit.target: The .avhdx and .vhdx files will merge, and when complete, the .avhdx file will be deleted from the file system.

trans-unit.source: **Tip:** You can use Windows Powershell to delete a checkpoint by using the **Remove-VMSnapshot** cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: **Tip:** You can use Windows Powershell to delete a checkpoint by using the **Remove-VMSnapshot** cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Checkpoints are stored as .avhdx files in the same location as the .vhdx files for the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Checkpoints are stored as .avhdx files in the same location as the .vhdx files for the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: You should not delete the .avhdx files directly.
trans-unit.target: You should not delete the .avhdx files directly.

trans-unit.source: Change where checkpoint settings and save state files are stored
trans-unit.target: Change where checkpoint settings and save state files are stored

trans-unit.source: If the virtual machine has no checkpoints, you can change where the checkpoint configuration and saved state files are stored.
trans-unit.target: If the virtual machine has no checkpoints, you can change where the checkpoint configuration and saved state files are stored.

trans-unit.source: In **Hyper-V Manager**, right-click the name of the virtual machine, and click **Settings**.
trans-unit.target: In **Hyper-V Manager**, right-click the name of the virtual machine, and click **Settings**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Management** section, select **Checkpoints** or **Checkpoint File Location**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Management** section, select **Checkpoints** or **Checkpoint File Location**.

trans-unit.source: In **Checkpoint File Location**, enter the path to the folder where you would like to store the files.
trans-unit.target: In **Checkpoint File Location**, enter the path to the folder where you would like to store the files.

trans-unit.source: Click **Apply** to apply your changes.
trans-unit.target: Click **Apply** to apply your changes.

trans-unit.source: If you are done, click **OK** to close the dialog box.
trans-unit.target: If you are done, click **OK** to close the dialog box.

trans-unit.source: The default location for storing checkpoint configuration files is: %systemroot%\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows\Hyper-V\Snapshots.
trans-unit.target: The default location for storing checkpoint configuration files is: %systemroot%\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows\Hyper-V\Snapshots.

trans-unit.source: Rename a checkpoint
trans-unit.target: Rename a checkpoint

trans-unit.source: In **Hyper-V Manager**, select the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: In **Hyper-V Manager**, select the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the checkpoint, and then select **Rename**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the checkpoint, and then select **Rename**.

trans-unit.source: Enter in the new name for the checkpoint.
trans-unit.target: Enter in the new name for the checkpoint.

trans-unit.source: It must be less than 100 characters, and the field cannot be empty.
trans-unit.target: It must be less than 100 characters, and the field cannot be empty.

trans-unit.source: Click **ENTER** when you are done.
trans-unit.target: Click **ENTER** when you are done.

trans-unit.source: By default, the name of a checkpoint is the name of the virtual machine combined with the date and time the checkpoint was taken.
trans-unit.target: By default, the name of a checkpoint is the name of the virtual machine combined with the date and time the checkpoint was taken.

trans-unit.source: This is the standard format:
trans-unit.target: This is the standard format:

trans-unit.source: Names are limited to 100 characters or less, and the name cannot be blank.
trans-unit.target: Names are limited to 100 characters or less, and the name cannot be blank.
